title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Consumers around the world have stockpiled an extra $5.4tn of savings since Covid-19 began and are becoming increasingly confident about the economic outlook, paving the way for a strong rebound.

Households accumulated the excess — defined as the additional savings compared with the 2019 spending pattern and equating to more than 6 per cent of global gross domestic product — by the end of the first quarter of this year, according to estimates by credit rating agency Moody's.

Booming global consumer confidence suggests shoppers will be willing to spend again as soon as businesses reopen when virus restrictions are eased.

In the first three months of 2021, the Conference Board global consumer confidence index hit its highest level since records began in 2005, with significant uplifts in all regions of the world. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • Joe Biden's administration will invest $1.7bn in federal funds to tackle Covid-19 variants. Half of US adults have now received at least one Covid-19 vaccine dose as the country prepares to resume the use of the Johnson & Johnson jab.

  • Seventy-seven cases of a variant linked to a surge in India have been found in the UK. Health officials said they were assessing whether the variant is more transmissible and vaccine evasive than other forms of the virus.

  • Australia is to ask the EU to lift export restrictions on vaccines. Canberra has blamed the EU for delays affecting 3m doses of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine.

  • Italy has held talks with several manufacturers about starting production of mRNA-based Covid-19 vaccines in the country, in the latest sign that European officials want to deepen those supplies over other types of shot.

  • UK prime minister Boris Johnson has cancelled a planned trip to India this month as the country battles a surge in coronavirus cases that is overwhelming hospitals. India's currency, the rupee, is suffering as investors' concerns grow.

Follow the latest news on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update email newsletter.

In the news

Top European football clubs sign up to breakaway Super League A dozen of Europe's wealthiest football clubs, including Spain's Real Madrid and England's Manchester United as well as Italy's AC Milan, have agreed to join a breakaway “Super League” competition that aims to supersede the Champions League. Top clubs in France and Germany, two of Europe's richest footballing countries, have so far refused to join the project. For updates of the business of sport, sign-up to our weekly Scoreboard email.

GameStop chief executive to step down The US video game retailer that was at the centre of a share-dealing frenzy earlier this year said its chief executive, George Sherman, would step down by August at the latest. The Texas-based company said in its annual report in March that it was evaluating its leadership, and has hired a company to help with its succession plans.

US and China pledge joint action on climate change John Kerry and Xie Zhenhua, the climate envoys for the world's two biggest economies, have vowed to co-operate “to tackle the climate crisis”, making a commitment to “concrete actions in the 2020s”. The pledge followed two days of high-stakes meetings in Shanghai and came ahead of a US summit this week, billed as a showcase for Biden's new climate policies.

Navalny moved to prison hospital Russia's prison service said on Monday it had moved jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny to a prison hospital. The move follows warnings from the anti-corruption activist's supporters that his life was “hanging by a thread”, 19 days into a hunger strike.  

  • The Czech Republic is to expel 18 Russian diplomats over suspicions that Russia's security services were involved in explosions at a Czech ammunition dump in 2014. In retaliation Russia has ordered 20 Czech diplomats to leave the country.

Dispute over Trump tax change threatens infrastructure bill A fight over Donald Trump's 2017 tax reforms stands in the way of Joe Biden's $2tn infrastructure proposals, with US lawmakers from both parties threatening to oppose any tax and spending plan that does not reverse a critical provision of Trump's changes.

Saudi and Iranian officials hold talks Senior Saudi and Iranian officials have been holding direct talks in a bid to repair relations, the Financial Times reported over the weekend. The negotiations, which took place in Baghdad this month, are the first between the two regional rivals for five years.

Royal family mourns Prince Philip Britain's Royal Family paid their final respects to Prince Philip on Saturday during a pared-down service in line with Covid-19 restrictions. The Queen, who celebrates her 95th birthday this week, sat alone during the service at St George's Chapel, Windsor attended by 30 family members. 

  • Mary Lou McDonald, leader of Northern Ireland's biggest Republican party Sinn Féin, has apologised for the IRA's killing of Prince Philip's uncle Lord Mountbatten more than 40 years ago.

The day ahead

Chauvin trial Attorneys in the trial of the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin are set to make their closing arguments today. Chauvin is accused of killing George Floyd, an unarmed black man, by kneeling on his neck for more than nine minutes until he stopped breathing. Meanwhile, calls to defund the police are growing in the US.

Earnings round-up Investors will be hoping for signs of recovery in the airline industry when United Airlines reports earnings today. Consumer goods group Coca-Cola and technology company IBM also release results.

Australia-New Zealand travel bubble The launch of an Australia-New Zealand quarantine-free “travel bubble” on Monday could provide a template elsewhere and pave the way for an airline industry recovery, according to the countries' leading carriers.

What else we're reading

The US infrastructure most in need of investment is human President Joe Biden's infrastructure plan includes $400bn for home healthcare and $25bn for childcare. Nearly all Republicans, and some centrist Democrats, are worried about this expanded definition of infrastructure. But “building back better” should involve bolstering such services, writes Rana Foroohar.

  • The one liberal critique that has the capacity to foul up the politics of Biden's infrastructure bill is the idea that it is fiscally too progressive, Edward Luce wrote in Swamp Notes. Sign up here.

US lawmakers warn of Libor chaos Thousands of loan, bond and derivatives contracts, adding up to an eye-watering notional sum of $200tn, still use the US-dollar version of the London interbank offered rate (Libor) to govern interest payments more than a decade after a rate-fixing scandal. Now lawmakers and regulators are making a plea to speed up the transition to an alternative reference rate ahead of a mid-2023 deadline.

Wirecard inquiry: Germany's elite exposed The inquiry into Wirecard — which revealed a €1.9bn black hole in the company's finances — has electrified Berlin's political class and led to a swath of resignations. The question is: why did regulators fail to spot one of the country's worst-ever corporate frauds?

Inside Jordan's royal crisis After Prince Hamzah was passed over for a position overseeing military intelligence services, he began courting tribal groups angry about the faltering economy and a loss of access to King Abdullah. That tactic brought the ambitious prince and the rest of the ruling family into open conflict two weeks ago.

Gaming inspires worlds of virtual work As we emerge from lockdowns and into hybrid working, employees are unlikely to be in the office all together every day — and some companies are going fully remote permanently. VR tools can help avoid Zoom fatigue and encourage more natural exchanges — or “water cooler” moments.

  • Get ready for the new politics of resentment in the office, writes Pilita Clark, as staff prepare to return. One worker's agonising time on furlough was another's blissful paid holiday.

Podcast of the day
